OpenSpecy reference libraries Absorbance units. derivative absolute first derivative transformed, nobaseline baseline corrected, raw rawest form reference spectra (recommended except advanced uses). previously mentioned libraries Raman FTIR spectra . mediod_{derivative nobasline} mediod compressed library version libraries critical spectra , model{derivative nobasline} exception multinomial regression approach identification. example use data("test_lib") subsampled version derivative library data("raman_hdpe") unprocessed Raman spectrum absorbance units HDPE plastic. spectra processed similarly library specifications, can identify spectra using match_spec(). Whichever library choose, need get spectra similar enough format use comparison. add_library_metadata add_object_metadata options specify column name metadata want add metadata top_n specifies many matches want. example just identified single spectrum library can also send OpenSpecy object multiple spectra. output matches data.table least 3 columns, object_id tells column names spectra x, library_id tells column names library matched . match_val value Pearson correlation coefficient (default) correlation specified ... using model identification option match_val model confidence. output example returned correct material type, HDPE, top match. using Pearson correlation, 0.7 good threshold use positive ID. example, top match greater threshold disregard matches. matches threshold, proclaim spectrum unknown identity. ’ll also notice example matched library Raman FTIR spectra Raman spectra highest hits, rationale lazily matching library . want just match library FTIR Raman spectra, can first filter library using filter_spec() using SpectrumType.
code: data("test_lib") data("raman_hdpe")  processed <- process_spec(x = raman_hdpe,                            conform_spec = F, #We will conform during matching.                            smooth_intens = T #Conducts the default derivative transformation.                            )  # Check to make sure that the signal to noise ratio of the processed spectra is # greater than 10. print(sig_noise(processed) > 10)  #Plot to assess the accuracy of the processing visually plotly_spec(raman_hdpe, processed) matches <- match_spec(x = processed, library = test_lib, conform = T,                       add_library_metadata = "sample_name", top_n = 5)[order(match_val, decreasing = T)] print(matches[,c("object_id", "library_id", "match_val", "SpectrumType",                  "SpectrumIdentity")])

text: Sometimes spectroscopy task want perform identify particles spectral map. especially common microplastic analysis spectral map used image sample spectral information used differentiate microplastic particles nonplastic particles. addition material id, one often wants measure shape size particles. brute force technique, one first identify every spectrum map, use thresholding image analysis measure particles. title: Open Specy Package Tutorial
code: #Test library data("test_lib")  #Example hyperspectral image with one cellulose acetate particle in the middle of it.  test_map <- read_any(read_extdata("CA_tiny_map.zip"))  #Process the map to conform to the library.  test_map_processed <- process_spec(test_map, conform_spec_args = list(   range = test_lib$wavenumber, res = NULL)   )  #Identify every spectrum in the map.  identities <- match_spec(test_map_processed, test_lib, order = test_map,                          add_library_metadata = "sample_name", top_n = 1)  #Relabel any spectra with low correlation coefficients.  features <- ifelse(identities$match_val > 0.7,                    tolower(identities$polymer_class), "unknown")  #Use spectra identities to identify particle regions as those that have the same material type and are touching.  id_map <- def_features(x = test_map_processed, features = features)  id_map$metadata$identities <- features # Also should probably be implemented automatically in the function when a # character value is provided.  heatmap_spec(id_map, z = id_map$metadata$identities)  # Collapses spectra to their median for each particle test_collapsed <- collapse_spec(id_map)  # Plot spectra for each identified particle plot(test_collapsed, offset = 1, legend_var = "feature_id")

title: Open Specy Package Tutorial
code: # Read in test library data("test_lib")  # Example dataset with one cellulose acetate particle.Conduct spatial smoothing to average each spectrum using adjacent spectra.  test_map <- read_any(read_extdata("CA_tiny_map.zip"),                         spectral_smooth = T,                      sigma = c(1, 1, 1))  # Characterize the signal times noise to determine where particle regions are.   snr <- sig_noise(test_map, metric = "sig_times_noise")  # Use this to find your particles and the idal signal times noise value to use for thresholding.  heatmap_spec(test_map, z = snr)  # Define the feature regions based on the threshold. Pixels from the background in the heatmap above were below 0.05 while my particle's pixels were above so I set snr > 0.05.   id_map <- def_features(x = test_map, features = snr > 0.05)   # Check that the thresholding worked as expected. Here we see a single particle region identified separate from the background.  heatmap_spec(id_map, z = id_map$metadata$feature_id)  # Collapse the spectra to their medians based on the threshold. Important to # note here that the particles with id -88 are anything from the FALSE values # so they should be your background.  collapsed_id_map <- id_map |>   collapse_spec()  # Process the collapsed spectra to have the same transformation and units as the library.  id_map_processed <- process_spec(collapsed_id_map, conform_spec_args = list(   range = test_lib$wavenumber, res = NULL)   )  # Check the spectra for the background and particle. Background has considerable signal in it too suggesting double bounce along the edges of the particle.  plot(id_map_processed, offset = 1, legend_var = "feature_id")  # Get the matches of the collapsed spectra for the particles. matches <- match_spec(id_map_processed, test_lib,                       add_library_metadata = "sample_name", top_n = 1)

what: Analyze, Process, Identify, and Share Raman and (FT)IR Spectra
title: Analyze, Process, Identify, and Share Raman and (FT)IR Spectra
text: Analyze, Process, Identify, Share Raman (FT)IR Spectra Raman (FT)IR spectral analysis tool plastic particles environmental samples (Cowger et al. 2021, doi: 10.1021/acs.analchem.1c00123). read_any(), Open Specy provides single function reading individual, batch, map spectral data files like .asp, .csv, .jdx, .spc, .spa, .0, .zip. process_spec() simplifies processing spectra, including smoothing, baseline correction, range restriction flattening, intensity conversions, wavenumber alignment, min-max normalization. Spectra can identified batch using onboard reference library (Cowger et al. 2020, doi: 10.1177/0003702820929064) using match_spec(). Shiny app available via run_app() online https://www.openanalysis.org/openspecy/.

what: Simple workflow for single spectral identification
title: Analyze, Process, Identify, and Share Raman and (FT)IR Spectra
text: See package vignette detailed standard operating procedure.
code: # Fetch current spectral library from https://osf.io/x7dpz/ get_lib("derivative")  # Load library into global environment spec_lib <- load_lib("derivative")  # Read sample spectrum raman_hdpe <- read_extdata("raman_hdpe.csv") |>    read_any()  # Look at the spectrum plotly_spec(raman_hdpe)  # Process the spectra and conform it to the library format raman_proc <- raman_hdpe |>   process_spec(conform_spec_args = list(range = spec_lib$wavenumbers),                 smooth_intens = T, make_rel = T)  # Compare raw and processed spectra plotly_spec(raman_hdpe, raman_proc)  top_matches <- match_spec(raman_proc, library = spec_lib, na.rm = T, top_n = 5,                           add_library_metadata = "sample_name",                           add_object_metadata = "col_id")  # Print the top 5 results with relevant metadata top_matches[, c("object_id", "library_id", "match_val", "SpectrumType",                 "SpectrumIdentity")]  # Get all metadata for the matches get_metadata(spec_lib, logic = top_matches$library_id)

title: Adjust spectral intensities to standard absorbance units. — adj_intens
text: Many Open Specy functions assume spectrum absorbance units. example, see subtr_baseline(). run functions properly, need first convert spectra transmittance reflectance absorbance using function. transmittance adjustment uses \(log(1 / T)\) calculation correct system particle characteristics. reflectance adjustment uses Kubelka-Munk equation \((1 - R)^2 / 2R\). assume reflectance intensity percent 1-100 first correct intensity dividing 100 fits form expected equation.

title: Create OpenSpecy objects — as_OpenSpecy
text: x depending method, list OpenSpecy parameters, vector wavenumbers spectra, data.frame full spectrum classic Open Specy format. session_id logical. Whether add session ID metadata. session ID based current session info metadata spectra return equal session info changes. Sometimes desirable. colnames names wavenumber column spectra column, makes assumptions based column names placement NULL. spectra spectral intensities formatted data.table one column per spectrum. metadata metadata spectrum one row per spectrum, see details. attributes list attributes describing critical aspects interpreting spectra. see details. coords spatial coordinates spectra. comma_decimal logical(1) whether commas may represent decimals. n number spectra generate spatial coordinate grid . ... additional arguments passed submethods.

title: Create OpenSpecy objects — as_OpenSpecy
text: as_OpenSpecy() OpenSpecy() returns three part lists described details. is_OpenSpecy() returns TRUE object OpenSpecy FALSE . gen_grid() returns data.table x y coordinates use generating spatial grid spectra one specified data.

title: Create OpenSpecy objects — as_OpenSpecy
text: as_OpenSpecy() converts spectral datasets three part list; first vector wavenumbers spectra, second data.table spectral intensities ordered columns, third item another data.table metadata user provides harvested files . metadata argument may contain named list following details (* = minimum recommended). file_name* file name, defaults basename() specified user_name* User name, e.g. "Win Cowger" contact_info Contact information, e.g. "1-513-673-8956, wincowger@gmail.com" organization Affiliation, e.g. "University California, Riverside" citation Data citation, e.g. "Primpke, S., Wirth, M., Lorenz, C., & Gerdts, G. (2018). Reference database design automated analysis microplastic samples based Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. Analytical Bioanalytical Chemistry. doi:10.1007/s00216-018-1156-x " spectrum_type* Raman FTIR spectrum_identity* Material/polymer analyzed, e.g. "Polystyrene" material_form Form material analyzed, e.g. textile fiber, rubber band, sphere, granule material_phase Phase material analyzed (liquid, gas, solid) material_producer Producer material analyzed, e.g. Dow material_purity Purity material analyzed, e.g. 99.98% material_quality Quality material analyzed, e.g. consumer product, manufacturer material, analytical standard, environmental sample material_color Color material analyzed, e.g. blue, #0000ff, (0, 0, 255) material_other material description, e.g. 5 µm diameter fibers, 1 mm spherical particles cas_number CAS number, e.g. 9003-53-6 instrument_used Instrument used, e.g. Horiba LabRam instrument_accessories Instrument accessories, e.g. Focal Plane Array, CCD instrument_mode Instrument modes/settings, e.g. transmission, reflectance intensity_units* Units intensity values spectrum, options transmittance, reflectance, absorbance spectral_resolution Spectral resolution, e.g. 4/cm laser_light_used Wavelength laser/light used, e.g. 785 nm number_of_accumulations Number accumulations, e.g 5 total_acquisition_time_s Total acquisition time (s), e.g. 10 s data_processing_procedure Data processing procedure, e.g. spikefilter, baseline correction, none level_of_confidence_in_identification Level confidence identification, e.g. 99% other_info information license license shared spectrum; defaults "CC -NC" (see https://creativecommons.org/licenses/-nc/4.0/ details). creative commons license allowed, example, CC0 CC session_id unique user session identifier; populated automatically paste(digest(Sys.info()), digest(sessionInfo()),   sep = "/") file_id unique file identifier; populated automatically digest(object[c("wavenumber", "spectra")]) attributes argument may contain named list following details, set, used automate transformations warning messages: intensity_units supported options include "absorbance", "transmittance", "reflectance" derivative_order supported options include "0", "1", "2" baseline supported options include "raw" "nobaseline" spectra_type supported options include "ftir" "raman"

text: adj_res() conform_res() helper functions align wavenumbers terms spectral resolution. adj_neg() converts numeric intensities y < 1 values >= 1, keeping absolute differences intensity values shifting value minimum intensity. make_rel() converts intensities y relative values 0 1 using standard normalization equation. na.rm TRUE, missing values removed computation proceeds.

title: Identify and filter spectra — cor_spec
text: match_spec() joins two OpenSpecy objects metadata based similarity. cor_spec() correlates two OpenSpecy objects, typically one knowns one unknowns. ident_spec() retrieves top match values correlation matrix formats metadata. get_metadata() retrieves metadata OpenSpecy objects. max_cor_named() formats top correlation values correlation matrix named vector. filter_spec() filters Open Specy object. fill_spec() adds filler values OpenSpecy object intensities. os_similarity() EXPERIMENTAL, returns single similarity metric two OpenSpecy objects based method used.

title: Identify and filter spectra — cor_spec
code: cor_spec(x, ...)  # Default S3 method cor_spec(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' cor_spec(x, library, na.rm = T, conform = F, type = "roll", ...)  match_spec(x, ...)  # Default S3 method match_spec(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' match_spec(   x,   library,   na.rm = T,   conform = F,   type = "roll",   top_n = NULL,   order = NULL,   add_library_metadata = NULL,   add_object_metadata = NULL,   fill = NULL,   ... )  ident_spec(   cor_matrix,   x,   library,   top_n = NULL,   add_library_metadata = NULL,   add_object_metadata = NULL,   ... )  get_metadata(x, ...)  # Default S3 method get_metadata(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' get_metadata(x, logic, rm_empty = TRUE, ...)  max_cor_named(cor_matrix, na.rm = T)  filter_spec(x, ...)  # Default S3 method filter_spec(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' filter_spec(x, logic, ...)  ai_classify(x, ...)  # Default S3 method ai_classify(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' ai_classify(x, library, fill = NULL, ...)  fill_spec(x, ...)  # Default S3 method fill_spec(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' fill_spec(x, fill, ...)  os_similarity(x, ...)  # Default S3 method os_similarity(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' os_similarity(x, y, method = "hamming", na.rm = T, ...)

title: Identify and filter spectra — cor_spec
text: x OpenSpecy object, typically unknowns. library OpenSpecy glmnet object representing reference library spectra model use identification. na.rm logical; indicating whether missing values removed calculating correlations. Default TRUE. conform Whether conform spectra library wavenumbers . type type conformation make returned conform_spec() top_n integer; specifying number top matches return. NULL (default), matches returned. order OpenSpecy used sorting, ideally unprocessed one; NULL skips sorting. add_library_metadata name column library metadata joined; NULL want join. add_object_metadata name column object metadata joined; NULL want join. fill OpenSpecy object single spectrum used fill missing values alignment AI classification. cor_matrix correlation matrix object library, can returned cor_spec() logic logical numeric vector describing spectra keep. rm_empty logical; whether remove empty columns metadata. y OpenSpecy object perform similarity search x. method type similarity metric return. ... additional arguments passed cor().

title: Identify and filter spectra — cor_spec
text: match_spec() ident_spec() return data.table-class() containing correlations spectra library. table three columns: object_id, library_id, match_val. row represents unique pairwise correlation spectrum object spectrum library. top_n specified, top top_n matches object spectrum returned. add_library_metadata .character, library metadata added output. add_object_metadata .character, object metadata added output. filter_spec() returns OpenSpecy object. fill_spec() returns OpenSpecy object. cor_spec() returns correlation matrix. get_metadata() returns data.table-class() metadata columns information. os_similarity() returns single numeric value representing type similarity metric requested. 'wavenumber' similarity based proportion wavenumber values overlap two objects, 'metadata' proportion metadata column names, 'hamming' something similar hamming distance discretize spectra OpenSpecy object wavenumber intensity values relate wavenumber intensity value distributions mean difference min-max normalized space. 'pca' tests distance OpenSpecy objects PCA space using first 4 component values calculating max-range normalized distance mean components. first two metrics pretty straightforward definitely ready go, 'hamming' 'pca' metrics pretty experimental appear working current test cases.

title: Process Spectra — process_spec
text: process_spec() monolithic wrapper function spectral processing steps.

title: Process Spectra — process_spec
code: process_spec(x, ...)  # Default S3 method process_spec(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' process_spec(   x,   active = TRUE,   adj_intens = FALSE,   adj_intens_args = list(type = "none"),   conform_spec = TRUE,   conform_spec_args = list(range = NULL, res = 5, type = "interp"),   restrict_range = FALSE,   restrict_range_args = list(min = 0, max = 6000),   flatten_range = FALSE,   flatten_range_args = list(min = 2200, max = 2420),   subtr_baseline = FALSE,   subtr_baseline_args = list(type = "polynomial", degree = 8, raw = FALSE, baseline =     NULL),   smooth_intens = TRUE,   smooth_intens_args = list(polynomial = 3, window = 11, derivative = 1, abs = TRUE),   make_rel = TRUE,   make_rel_args = list(na.rm = TRUE),   ... )

title: Process Spectra — process_spec
text: x OpenSpecy object. active logical; indicating whether perform processing. TRUE, processing steps applied. FALSE, original data returned. adj_intens logical; describing whether adjust intensity units. adj_intens_args named list arguments passed adj_intens(). conform_spec logical; whether conform spectra new wavenumber range resolution. conform_spec_args named list arguments passed conform_spec(). restrict_range logical; indicating whether restrict wavenumber range spectra. restrict_range_args named list arguments passed restrict_range(). flatten_range logical; indicating whether flatten range around carbon dioxide region. flatten_range_args named list arguments passed flatten_range(). subtr_baseline logical; indicating whether subtract baseline spectra. subtr_baseline_args named list arguments passed subtr_baseline(). smooth_intens logical; indicating whether apply smoothing filter spectra. smooth_intens_args named list arguments passed smooth_intens(). make_rel logical; TRUE spectra automatically normalized make_rel(). make_rel_args named list arguments passed make_rel(). na.rm Whether allow NA set NA values ... arguments passed subfunctions.

title: Process Spectra — process_spec
text: process_spec() returns OpenSpecy object processed spectra based specified parameters.

title: Process Spectra — process_spec
code: data("raman_hdpe") plot(raman_hdpe)   # Process spectra with range restriction and baseline subtraction process_spec(raman_hdpe,              restrict_range = TRUE,              restrict_range_args = list(min = 500, max = 3000),              subtr_baseline = TRUE,              subtr_baseline_args = list(type = "polynomial",                                         polynomial = 8)) |>   plot()   # Process spectra with smoothing and derivative process_spec(raman_hdpe,              smooth_intens = TRUE,              smooth_intens_args = list(                polynomial = 3,                window = 11,                derivative = 1                )              ) |>   plot()

title: Read spectral data — read_text
text: Functions reading spectral data external file types. Currently supported reading formats .csv text files, .asp, .spa, .spc, .xyz, .jdx. Additionally, .0 (OPUS) .dat (ENVI) files supported via read_opus() read_envi(), respectively. read_zip() takes files listed . Note proprietary file formats like .0, .asp, .spa poorly supported likely still work cases.

title: Read spectral data from Bruker OPUS binary files — read_opus
code: read_opus(   file,   metadata = list(file_name = basename(file), user_name = NULL, contact_info = NULL,     organization = NULL, citation = NULL, spectrum_type = NULL, spectrum_identity = NULL,     material_form = NULL, material_phase = NULL, material_producer = NULL,     material_purity = NULL, material_quality = NULL, material_color = NULL,     material_other = NULL, cas_number = NULL, instrument_used = NULL,     instrument_accessories = NULL, instrument_mode = NULL, spectral_resolution = NULL,     laser_light_used = NULL, number_of_accumulations = NULL,           total_acquisition_time_s = NULL, data_processing_procedure = NULL,     level_of_confidence_in_identification = NULL, other_info = NULL, license =     "CC BY-NC"),   type = "spec",   digits = 1L,   atm_comp_minus4offset = FALSE )

title: Read spectral data from Bruker OPUS binary files — read_opus
text: file character vector path file(s). metadata named list metadata; see as_OpenSpecy() details. type character vector spectra types extract OPUS binary file. Default "spec", extract final spectra, e.g. expressed absorbance (named AB Bruker OPUS programs). Possible additional values character vector supplied type "spec_no_atm_comp" (spectrum sample without compensation atmospheric gases, water vapor /carbon dioxide), "sc_sample" (single channel spectrum sample measurement), "sc_ref" (single channel spectrum reference measurement), "ig_sample" (interferogram sample measurement) "ig_ref" (interferogram reference measurement). digits Integer specifies number decimal places used round wavenumbers (values x-variables). atm_comp_minus4offset Logical whether spectra atmospheric compensation read offset -4 bytes Bruker OPUS files; default FALSE.

what: Read a Bruker OPUS spectrum binary raw string — read_opus_raw
title: Read a Bruker OPUS spectrum binary raw string — read_opus_raw
text: Read single binary acquired Bruker Vertex FTIR Instrument

title: Read a Bruker OPUS spectrum binary raw string — read_opus_raw
code: read_opus_raw(rw, type = "spec", atm_comp_minus4offset = FALSE)

title: Read a Bruker OPUS spectrum binary raw string — read_opus_raw
text: rw raw vector type character vector spectra types extract OPUS binary file. Default "spec", extract final spectra, e.g. expressed absorbance (named AB Bruker OPUS programs). Possible additional values character vector supplied type "spec_no_atm_comp" (spectrum sample without compensation atmospheric gases, water vapor /carbon dioxide), "sc_sample" (single channel spectrum sample measurement), "sc_ref" (single channel spectrum reference measurement), "ig_sample" (interferogram sample measurement) "ig_ref" (interferogram reference measurement). atm_comp_minus4offset logical; whether spectra atmospheric compensation read offset -4 bytes Bruker OPUS files. Default FALSE.

title: Read a Bruker OPUS spectrum binary raw string — read_opus_raw
text: list 10 elements: metadata data.frame containing metadata OPUS file. spec "spec" requested type option, matrix spectrum sample (otherwise set NULL). spec_no_atm_comp "spec_no_atm_comp" requested type option, matrix spectrum sample without atmospheric compensation (otherwise set NULL). sc_sample "sc_sample" requested type option, matrix single channel spectrum sample (otherwise set NULL). sc_ref "sc_ref" requested type option, matrix single channel spectrum reference (otherwise set NULL). ig_sample "ig_sample" requested type option, matrix interferogram sample (otherwise set NULL). ig_ref "ig_ref" requested type option, matrix interferogram reference (otherwise set NULL). wavenumbers "spec" "spec_no_atm_comp" requested type option, numeric vector wavenumbers spectrum sample (otherwise set NULL). wavenumbers_sc_sample "sc_sample" requested type option, numeric vector wavenumbers single channel spectrum sample (otherwise set NULL). wavenumbers_sc_ref "sc_ref" requested type option, numeric vector wavenumbers single channel spectrum reference (otherwise set NULL).

title: Read a Bruker OPUS spectrum binary raw string — read_opus_raw
text: type spectra returned function using type = "spec" depends setting Bruker instrument: typically, can either absorbance reflectance. type spectra extract file can also use Bruker's OPUS software naming conventions, follows: ScSm corresponds sc_sample ScRf corresponds sc_ref IgSm corresponds ig_sample IgRf corresponds ig_ref

title: Calculate signal and noise metrics for OpenSpecy objects — sig_noise
text: function calculates common signal noise metrics OpenSpecy objects.

title: Calculate signal and noise metrics for OpenSpecy objects — sig_noise
code: sig_noise(x, ...)  # Default S3 method sig_noise(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' sig_noise(   x,   metric = "run_sig_over_noise",   na.rm = TRUE,   prob = 0.5,   step = 20,   breaks = seq(min(unlist(x$spectra)), max(unlist(x$spectra)), length =     ((nrow(x$spectra)^(1/3)) * (max(unlist(x$spectra)) - min(unlist(x$spectra))))/(2 *     IQR(unlist(x$spectra)))),   sig_min = NULL,   sig_max = NULL,   noise_min = NULL,   noise_max = NULL,   abs = T,   spatial_smooth = F,   sigma = c(1, 1),   threshold = NULL,   ... )

title: Calculate signal and noise metrics for OpenSpecy objects — sig_noise
text: x OpenSpecy object. metric character; specifying desired metric calculate. Options include "sig" (mean intensity), "noise" (standard deviation intensity), "sig_times_noise" (absolute value signal times noise), "sig_over_noise" (absolute value signal / noise), "run_sig_over_noise" (absolute value signal / noise signal estimated max intensity noise estimated height low intensity region.), "log_tot_sig" (sum inverse log intensities, useful spectra  log units), "tot_sig" (sum intensities), "entropy" (Shannon entropy intensities).. na.rm logical; indicating whether missing values removed calculating signal noise. Default TRUE. prob numeric single value; probability retrieve quantile noise interpreted run_sig_over_noise option. step numeric; step size region look run_sig_over_noise option. breaks numeric; number positions breaks entropy calculation. Defaults infer decent value data. sig_min numeric; minimum wavenumber value signal region. sig_max numeric; maximum wavenumber value signal region. noise_min numeric; minimum wavenumber value noise region. noise_max numeric; maximum wavenumber value noise region. abs logical; whether return absolute value result spatial_smooth logical; whether spatially smooth sig/noise using xy coordinates gaussian smoother. sigma numeric; two value vector describing standard deviation smoother dimension, y specified first followed x, cases. threshold numeric; NULL, threshold set, otherwise use numeric value set target threshold true signal noise . function return logical value instead numeric threshold set. ... arguments passed subfunctions; currently used.

title: Calculate signal and noise metrics for OpenSpecy objects — sig_noise
text: numeric vector containing calculated metric spectrum OpenSpecy object logical value threshold set describing numbers equal (TRUE) threshold.

code: data("raman_hdpe")  sig_noise(raman_hdpe, metric = "sig") #> intensity  #>  101.1691  sig_noise(raman_hdpe, metric = "noise") #> intensity  #>  61.00777  sig_noise(raman_hdpe, metric = "sig_times_noise") #> intensity  #>    6172.1

title: Smooth spectral intensities — smooth_intens
text: smoother can enhance signal noise ratio data useing Savitzky-Golay Whittaker-Henderson filter.

title: Smooth spectral intensities — smooth_intens
code: smooth_intens(x, ...)  # Default S3 method smooth_intens(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' smooth_intens(   x,   polynomial = 3,   window = 11,   derivative = 1,   abs = TRUE,   lambda = 1600,   d = 2,   type = "sg",   lag = 2,   make_rel = TRUE,   ... )  calc_window_points(x, ...)  # Default S3 method calc_window_points(x, wavenum_width = 70, ...)  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' calc_window_points(x, wavenum_width = 70, ...)

title: Smooth spectral intensities — smooth_intens
text: x object class OpenSpecy vector calc_window_points(). polynomial polynomial order filter window number data points window, filter length (must odd). derivative derivative order want calculate derivative. Zero (default) derivative. abs logical; whether want calculate absolute value resulting output. lambda smoothing parameter Whittaker-Henderson smoothing, 50 results rough smoothing 10^4 results high level smoothing. d order differences use Whittaker-Henderson smoothing, typically set 2. type type smoothing use "wh" Whittaker-Henerson "sg" Savitzky-Golay. lag lag use numeric derivative calculation using Whittaker-Henderson. Greater values lead smoother derivatives, 1 2 common. make_rel logical; TRUE spectra automatically normalized make_rel(). wavenum_width width window want wavenumbers. ... arguments passed sgolay().

title: Smooth spectral intensities — smooth_intens
text: smooth_intens() returns OpenSpecy object. calc_window_points() returns single numberic vector object number points needed fill window can passed smooth_intens(). many applications, reusable specifying static number points.

title: Smooth spectral intensities — smooth_intens
text: Savitzky-Golay wrapper around filter function signal package improve integration Open Specy functions. typical good smooth can achieved 11 data point window 3rd 4th order polynomial. Whittaker-Henderson, code largely based whittaker() function pracma package. general Whittaker-Henderson expected slower robust Savitzky-Golay.

title: Smooth spectral intensities — smooth_intens
text: Savitzky , Golay MJ (1964). “Smoothing Differentiation Data Simplified Least Squares Procedures.” Analytical Chemistry, 36(8), 1627–1639.

what: Automated background subtraction for spectral data — subtr_baseline
title: Automated background subtraction for spectral data — subtr_baseline
text: baseline correction routine iteratively finds baseline spectrum using polynomial fitting methods accepts manual baseline.

title: Automated background subtraction for spectral data — subtr_baseline
code: subtr_baseline(x, ...)  # Default S3 method subtr_baseline(   x,   y,   type = "polynomial",   degree = 8,   raw = FALSE,   full = T,   remove_peaks = T,   refit_at_end = F,   crop_boundaries = F,   iterations = 10,   peak_width_mult = 3,   termination_diff = 0.05,   degree_part = 2,   bl_x = NULL,   bl_y = NULL,   make_rel = TRUE,   ... )  # S3 method for class 'OpenSpecy' subtr_baseline(   x,   type = "polynomial",   degree = 8,   raw = FALSE,   full = T,   remove_peaks = T,   refit_at_end = F,   crop_boundaries = F,   iterations = 10,   peak_width_mult = 3,   termination_diff = 0.05,   degree_part = 2,   baseline = list(wavenumber = NULL, spectra = NULL),   make_rel = TRUE,   ... )

title: Automated background subtraction for spectral data — subtr_baseline
text: x list object class OpenSpecy vector wavenumbers. y vector spectral intensities. type one "polynomial" "manual" depending desired baseline correction method. degree degree full spectrum polynomial. Must less number unique points raw FALSE. Typically, good fit can found 8th order polynomial. raw TRUE, use raw orthogonal polynomials. full logical, whether use full spectrum "imodpoly" partition "smodpoly". remove_peaks logical, whether remove peak regions first iteration. refit_at_end logical, whether refit polynomial end result (TRUE) use linear approximation. crop_boundaries logical, whether smartly crop boundaries match spectra based peak proximity. iterations number iterations automated baseline correction. peak_width_mult scaling factor width peak detection regions. termination_diff scaling factor ratio difference residual standard deviation terminate iterative fitting . degree_part degree polynomial "smodpoly". Must less number unique points. bl_x vector wavenumbers baseline. bl_y vector spectral intensities baseline. make_rel logical; TRUE, spectra automatically normalized make_rel(). baseline OpenSpecy object containing baseline data subtracted ("manual"). ... arguments passed poly() "smodpoly" parameters.

title: Automated background subtraction for spectral data — subtr_baseline
text: subtr_baseline() returns data frame containing two columns named "wavenumber" "intensity".

title: Automated background subtraction for spectral data — subtr_baseline
text: function supports two types "polynomial" automated baseline correction options. Default settings closest "imodpoly" iterative polynomial fitting based Zhao et al. (2007). Additionally options recommended "smodpoly" segmented iterative polynomial fitting enhanced peak detection S-Modpoly algorithm (https://github.com/jackma123-rgb/S-Modpoly), "manual" applying user-provided baseline.

title: Automated background subtraction for spectral data — subtr_baseline
text: Chen MS (2020). Michaelstchen/ModPolyFit. MATLAB. Retrieved https://github.com/michaelstchen/modPolyFit (Original work published July 28, 2015) Zhao J, Lui H, McLean DI, Zeng H (2007). “Automated Autofluorescence Background Subtraction Algorithm Biomedical Raman Spectroscopy.” Applied Spectroscopy, 61(11), 1225–1232. doi:10.1366/000370207782597003 . Jackma123 (2023). S-Modpoly: Segmented modified polynomial fitting spectral baseline correction. GitHub Repository. Retrieved https://github.com/jackma123-rgb/S-Modpoly.

text: Win Cowger, Zacharias Steinmetz
